subject: Re: [junit] New introduction to JUnit 4
msgSnippet: #: by Daniel Le Berre s words the mind was *winged* :# ... Sounds interesting, but I don t see the means. Can you place some lite on this?
messageBody:
#: by Daniel Le Berre's words the mind was *winged* :#
> Le mercredi 15 juin 2005 à 10:50 +0200, Alexandru Popescu a écrit :
>> #: by Daniel Le Berre's words the mind was *winged* :#
>> > Hi Kent,
>> >
>> > Le mardi 14 juin 2005 � 23:32 -0700, Kent Beck a �crit :
>> >> Gunjan Doshi has written a ten-minute introduction to JUnit 4 for those
>> >> already familiar with JUnit. You can find it here:
>> >> http://www.instrumentalservices.com/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&i
>> >> d=45&Itemid=52.
>> >>
>> >> Kent Beck
>> >> Three Rivers Institute
>> >>
>> >
>> > That introduction is quite nice. I am looking forward being able to use
>> > JUnit 4.
>> >
>> > Just one question:
>> >
>> > since there is no longer any static dependencies with Junit TestCase,
>> > should the tests be written in the class to be tested or in another
>> > class?
>> >
>> > I was used to create a test source folder with all my tests cases.
>> >
>> > Using annotations, I would prefer declaring the tests directly inside my
>> > class.
>> >
>> > Any hints about that?
>> >
>> > Daniel
>>
>> But this will lead to distribute your tests along with the real application. Why should you do this?
>>
>> :alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|
>>
>
> Nope. Since the code is annotated, I could use the annotations to clean
> the code before distributing it.
>
> Daniel

Sounds interesting, but I don't see the means. Can you place some lite on this?

:alex |.::the_mindstorm::.|
